moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bb5 a6
comment:
This move entails a loss of time and
White should be able to gain the advantage, but it is not as easy as one might
expect. There are two reasonable plans. White can either continue with Bxc6
and d3 with an extra tempo, or he can open the position with Bxc6 and Nxe5,
hoping to exploit Black's centralised king. Both plans are promising.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bb5 a6 5. Bxc6 dxc6 6. Nxe5 Nxe4 7. Nxe4 Qd4 8. O-O Qxe5 9. Re1 Be6 10. d4 Qf5 11. Bg5 Bd6
comment: This is normally given a question mark, but the real error only comes nextmove.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bb5 a6 5. Bxc6 dxc6 6. Nxe5 Nxe4 7. Nxe4 Qd4 8. O-O Qxe5 9. Re1 Be6 10. d4 Qf5 11. Bg5 Bd6 12. g4
comment:
This is probably less
effective than the simple 12.Qd2, when White has the same type of slight
advantage. 12...

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bb5 a6 5. Bxc6 dxc6 6. Nxe5 Nxe4 7. Nxe4 Qd4 8. O-O Qxe5 9. Re1 Be6 10. d4 Qf5 11. Bg5 Bd6 12. g4 Qg6
comment:
A serious error. After 12...Qd5 or 12...Qb5
White has no forcing continuation, and the weakening of his kingside resulting
from the move g4 improves Black's long-term chances for counterplay.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bb5 a6 5. Bxc6 dxc6 6. Nxe5 Nxe4 7. Nxe4 Qd4 8. O-O Qxe5 9. Re1 Be6 10. d4 Qf5 11. Bg5 Bd6 12. g4 Qg6 13. f4 f5
comment: The rest is a nightmare for Black:
